review.title: A framework for mining process models from emails logs
review.abstract: Due to its wide use in personal, but most importantly, professional contexts, email represents a valuable source of information that can be harvested for understanding, reengineering and repurposing undocumented business processes of companies and institutions. Towards this aim, a few researchers investigated the problem of extracting process oriented information from email logs in order to take benefit of the many available process mining techniques and tools. In this paper we go further in this direction, by proposing a new method for mining process models from email logs that leverage unsupervised machine learning techniques with little human involvement. Moreover, our method allows to semi-automatically label emails with activity names, that can be used for activity recognition in new incoming emails. A use case demonstrates the usefulness of the proposed solution using a modest in size, yet real-world, dataset containing emails that belong to two different process models.

sections.text: Figure 1 shows that our approach is a three-step process that generates a series of process models in the face of a series of emails as input. E-mails can be delivered by an individual, such as a student or researcher or an institution. To be clearer in the rest of the paper, we will provide some definitions: 1. Process model: is the general representation of all process instincts. Process model describes a business process that is applied to achieve a specific goal. It is an interconnected graph of nodes and edges that are applied during the process, and the edges that connect the nodes represent the flow between activities. Mainly, process mining techniques are applied to event logs to derive their corresponding process models. 2. Instance / case: An instance is a specific execution of the process model. There can be several ways to execute the same business process.

sections.heading: 3 Phase 1: Email Log Preprocessing
sections.text: The first step consists of a series of e-mails that are pre-processed to clean up and translate into a structured format that is suitable for mining. E-mails are unstructured data that should be translated into the format expected by the mining tools. Part of the content of the message may be useless for our analysis. For this reason, data cleanup is an important step. In addition, attributes that describe e-mails (used in similarity measurement) may be of different data types. Therefore, it is essential to perform some pre-processing and normalization of the data before starting the analysis. Below, we will describe the steps of cleansing, displaying and normalizing data.

sections.heading: 3.1 Cleansing
sections.text: We use the R statistical language text mining library to pre-process inbox mails. Emails can contain a lot of words or symbols that are not for our analysis, such as stopwords, numbers or punctuation marks. The R statistical language provides several built-in functions that can perform special word pre-processing tasks, such as removing stopwords, removing numbers, removing punctuation marks and lowering capitals, etc. This helps to optimize similarity measurement between the contents of emails.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed a framework for mining the process models underlying an e-mail log, which is capable of handling e-mails that are hung in different process models. Hierarchical and k-mean cluster algorithms are used to cluster e-mails by topic, then according to the process instance to which they belong, and finally for tagging e-mail activities. We demonstrated a use case that demonstrates the usefulness of the proposed solution based on logs of e-mails from two different process topics: scheduling and requests for conference travel allowances. In future work, we plan to implement the activity detection phase based on the clusters obtained. We will also examine how approaches to language activities can help define more precisely the activity event associated with an e-mail and activity loop. In addition, we will expand the framework by considering e-mails as an entity (rather than just one set of activities), but also by integrating it into one set of multiple entities.
